awd_titl_txt: Timing, Rates and History of Post-YTT (<74ka) Resurgent Uplift of Samosir Island, Toba, Sumatra
awd_abstract_narration:
Large calderas like Toba, Sumatra are the sites of the most devastating natural events on Earth, supereruptions. With their potential to cause regional devastation and global disaster, understanding the processes and timescales of these supervolcanoes is crucial to being able to address potential hazards. While the climactic eruptions are the main event, these are just instances that punctuate long periods of relative calm. It is during these "resurgent" periods that supervolcanoes recover and readjust before the next eruption cycle. Critical information about the pre- and post-climactic activity of a supervolcano is encoded during this period, yet despite decades of research, resurgence remains poorly understood. This is of concern because most hazardous calderas today are in a resurgent stage. The goal of this project is to understand the timescale, rates, duration, and mechanisms that occur at large resurgent calderas through a case study of the Toba caldera, Sumatra, the Earth's most recent supervolcano.

Since the climactic eruption of 2500 km^3 of magma 74 ka as the Young Toba Tuff (YTT), there is evidence of several small eruptions within the Toba caldera as well over 1 km of vertical uplift of the caldera floor to form the island of Samosir. The hypothesis that remnant magma left after the climactic eruption was the source of this resurgence will be addressed through a program of stratigraphic correlation and age dating to reveal the spatiotemporal pattern of eruptions and the rate and motivating force for the uplift.  Post YTT lavas are to be dated using coupled U-series and (U/Th)/He age determinations in zircon to resolve eruption ages and the rate and duration of uplift of Samosir are to be investigated using a combination of C-14 age dating and time control through stratigraphic correlation using paleomagnetic properties of uplifted lake sediments on Samosir. Toba's relative youth is a unique advantage among large calderas and it is anticipated that this project will reveal unprecedented details of the post-climatic history and longevity of a large caldera and its magmatic system that can be used to inform more sophisticated numerical models of caldera mechanics than currently available. Furthermore, the serendipitous opportunity to address previously recalcitrant aspects of the region's geomagnetic field will attract further attention to Toba and this work. Graduate students will receive interdisciplinary training in modern caldera science and associated geochronology within an international collaborative framework with colleagues in USA, Germany, Australia, and Indonesia. The science conducted will give further impetus to efforts to develop a UNESCO Geopark at Toba.

por.por_cntn:
Supereruptions, such as the Youngest Toba Tuff eruption (YTT) 74,000 years ago from the Toba supervolcano in Sumatra, are second only to asteroid impacts in their disruption to the Earth system. As such, supereruptions are natural "Black Swans" 'that society needs to anticipate and understand. Accordingly, the conditions that lead to the formation of magma systems that eventually erupt as supereruptions, the dynamics of such eruptions, caldera-formation, and the associated hazards have received significant attention from the volcanological community. However, the post-supereruption history, known as the post-caldera or resurgent stage, has received much less attention. This is concerning because supervolcanoes remain active and continue to pose hazards long after the supereruption, and all active supervolcanoes on Earth today are in this phase of their life cycles. Understanding the post-supereruption life of supervolcanoes is therefore a crucial part of understanding their full hazard potential.

In this project we sought to unravel the post-supereruption history of the Toba supervolcano, by investigating the timing, characteristics, and mechanisms of the resurgent uplift of the caldera floor and the post-caldera eruptions. Toba is a compelling natural laboratory to do this work because its' long term geological and magmatic history is well known. Moreover, because it is so geologically young, Toba's post-caldera and resurgence record is quite complete and recent enough to be considered potentially active. Conversely, this youth poses challenges to obtain the accurate and precise ages that are critical if our investigation was to bear fruit.  We overcame these challenges through a multi-technique age dating approach that integrated Carbon-14 and paleomagnetism on lake sediments and Argon40-Argon39, and Uranium-Thorium/Helium in zircon on volcanic lithologies coupled to statistical and thermal modeling.

Our work has revealed the following:

1)    Resurgent uplift of Samosir Island started approximately 5000 years after the YTT supereruption.

2)    Samosir Island emerged from Lake Toba ~36,000 years ago indicating at least 30,000 years of underwater uplift.

3)    Uplift was piecemeal as Samosir was broken up into several differentially uplifting blocks.

4)    The rate of uplift decreased over time but continued till at least 2000 years ago.

5)    The motivating force for uplift was the intrusive impulse of remnant magma.

6)    Post-caldera volcanism on Samosir began 5000 years ago and continued till at least 13,000 years after the supereruption.

7)    The eruptions on Samosir were of remnant magma in a solid state.

8)    Elsewhere in the caldera, post-caldera volcanism continued till at least 30,000 years younging towards the north.

9)    In 2010 Sinabung volcano, 30 km north of Toba caldera started erupting and has continued to the present day. The magmas erupted at Sinabung share chemical and geochronological characteristics with the Toba post-caldera eruptions connoting that Sinabung may be a post-caldera volcano of the Toba supervolcano.

10) Eruptive activity at Sinabung volcano is initiated by recharge by new magma from as deep at 30 km and traverse a mush-dominated plumbing system.

These results reveal a very active post-supereruption recovery at Toba that extends to the present day and help us better assess the current hazard potential of Toba as well as at other active supervolcanoes on Earth. Results from this project also contributed to a new finding that the YTT supereruption at Toba is synchrononous with the antipodal Los Chocoyos (LCY) supereruption in Guatemala. This synchroneity is not statistically random and may record a serendipitous cause and effect where seismic energy associated with the YTT eruption initiated the high sulfur LCY supereruption on the other side of the Earth. This supereruption "double whammy" is a more compelling cause of volcanically induced Late Pleistocene climate change and associated impacts on hominid evolution than the YTT eruption itself.

Six female students received training in volcanology and professional development through this project and four of them gained valuable international experience through fieldwork as well as outreach and engagement with collaborators in Indonesia, Germany, and Australia. Furthermore, new collaborations with two other early career BIPOC researchers established during this project further enhances the impact of our human resource and broadening representation efforts of this project. A major international workshop we held on Samosir in 2018 brought home the global interest in Toba to Indonesian scientists and the population of Samosir alike, further underlining the importance of this geologic wonder. The project has resulted in two-way knowledge transfer with local geologists and populations supporting the region's efforts to develop a UNESCO Geopark based on the Toba supervolcano. Our work at Toba has involved local authorities and has established strong collaborations with the Toba Geopark, local universities, the regional Bhupathi (Regent) and the Samosir Office of Commerce and Industry. Outreach efforts are already impacting the entire region by imbuing the citizenry with a deeper understanding and appreciation of the volcanic hazard associated with Toba and Sinabung.
